comment.author: 78519276@N00
comment._content:
The hills look a bit like the Mournes or possibly the Cooley Mountains so that could put this anywhere between Omeath and Clogherhead (but probably closer to Omeath given how high the hills look).
But...the hills also remind me of the profile of the 12 Bens in Connemara so I could be way off!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Hooray! A "where is this?" photo. I was just about to request one because I'm stuck at home all week after being run over at the weekend.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I think the hills are a bit pointy for Louth/Down. I was thinking more West Cork.Let's see what streetview has to say on the matter.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: After a quick look on streetview it could be the Mournes or West Cork. Needs more investigation.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Roundstone?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The Dominican Monastery?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Because of this tower (rebuilt at the top) - goo.gl/maps/P0nD6 . Part of a monastery - "The village was founded in the mid 1820s by the celebrated Scottish engineer Alexander Nimmo who, as engineer for the Western District, built houses, roads and harbours throughout the West of Ireland. It was then settled by Scottish fisher folk. In 1835 a Franciscan Monastery was established in Roundstone and by the 1840s 75 houses had been built and the village supported an active fishing industry and a population of some 400 people. The village derives its name from the Irish “Cloch Na Ron” or Rock of the Seals. " - www.roundstone-connemara.com/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Yes!

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: That explains the Scottish Tam O Shanter cap!! ....The old boy must be one /or descendent of Nimmo's original settlers. Well done...that cap had me. Another NLI Super-Zoomable from Edward Tenison's "Kilronan Album" from 1858. Though here, it's a "Franciscan Monastery".( Dominican on OSI ).

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I haven't found any reference to the little step pyramid anywhere. There was a fashion for these for some reason.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There is also an old graveyard, now overgrown, south of the monastery. This could be steps at the bottom of a cross or other grave marker.

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: Maybe they are discussing the big Hurling match coming up!

comment.author: 44274283@N07
comment._content: From the angle it appears to be in the Fair Green - perhaps the steps leading up to some sort of a weighing station? Or a drinking trough?

comment.author: 54017078@N00
comment._content: The hats!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Re the date - the 1858 Tenison photo shows the buildings in a poor state, which fits with this 1863 letter via Trove describing "Distress in Roundstone" - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/115427859. By the time of this photo, the place is looking quite prosperous and newly whitewashed. And then by the time of the Lawrence photo, there are additional floors to the left-hand wing and a new belfry replacing the spire. Not much else helpful in Trove - is there something in the Irish press to help with the date?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I thought the plinth/steps might be that rectangular object marked in the graveyard, but there don't seem to be any gravestones or wooden crosses evident even after the famine hardships described in that letter.  Hmmm...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Thanks. I had been looking forward to whiling away the tedium on this site but it turns out computers (or at any rate, trying to match topography to maps) disagree with my injuries.
